stories.text:
Sorry for asking such a noob question, but I'm completely stumped. I can't seem to find any Android app that does the simple function of copying a website's URL and Title to the clipboard.

There are several Chrome extensions that do this, but no Android equivalent?

All existing "solutions" are web clippers that are tied to specific software, rather than an agnostic and barebone approach that I'm talking about.
stories.title: Ask HN: Android app for copying URL+Title to clipboard?
Why Jackpot is called a Jackpot
Game changing smartphone app gathers evidence of speeding

stories.text:
Hey, HN! When building user interfaces for smaller and mobile apps you've got quite a few tools to choose from. Figma and the like work great for them. But for the complex projects we do at our UX agency, those tools are a pain to use. Designing a control interface for an industrial machine in Figma doesn't make any fun. You often need to somehow hack the interactions you need into it.

To make prototyping complex interfaces easier, we built Antetype. With layouts that really adapt to changing content and (hopefully) easy-to-understand interaction options. For us, it really helps creating complex and working UIs – to test and validate ideas.

Antetype is also build on web concepts: That means you can use any HTML/CSS tricks you know and also any JS framework you require. We often use that to embed interactive 3D models or working charts (instead of static images).

Video of Antetype's features + prototypes built with it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SUBpJlLJrdY

Website with examples + demo videos: https://www.antetype.com

Register to download it (macOS only): https://cloud.antetype.com/register/

(You can use it entirely free. No water marks or restrictions. Our paid plan just takes care of hosting if you don't want to do it yourself.)

I would love to hear your thoughts – we released it to the public just a few weeks ago.
